title: CFTC: Commissioners Shouldn't Be Forced to Testify
summary: Agency asks appeals court to block contempt hearing, calling order for commissioners to appear in court unprecedented. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has asked an appeals court to block an order requiring three of its commissioners to testify over statements the agency published following a market-manipulation settlement.

title: Can Democrats Take Impeachment Seriously?
summary: If it's a straight party-line vote, they'll win in the House, fail in the Senate, and lose in America.. We have grown used to the daily bedlam, the nonstop freak-out that is the Trump White House. Nevertheless it should be noted the president's language and visage this week were especially wild. It's "treason," it's "a coup," it's a "hoax" and a "fraud," the whistleblower's information came from "a leaker or a spy," it's a political "hack job," it's "bulls-." He had a Travis Bickle moment-"You talkin' to me?"-with Jeffrey Mason of Reuters. He's careening around, growling and prowling like some preliterate King Lear. It's a reality show about a reality you don't want to be in.

title: Sports Illustrated Operator Cuts 25% of Staff
summary: Employees protest plan by TheMaven to recruit contract workers to cover sports. TheMaven Inc., which earlier this year licensed the rights to Sports Illustrated's print and digital publications, moved to eliminate about 40 positions at the sports media bible as part of a broader overhaul, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Biden Announces $15.2 Million Fundraising Haul in Third Quarter
summary: Sanders, Buttigieg raised more in the summer months. WASHINGTON-Former Vice President Joe Biden said he raised $15.2 million for his presidential campaign during the past three months, a drop-off from his initial fundraising foray that could put him at a disadvantage against some of his Democratic rivals.

title: Ron Perelman's Deluxe Entertainment Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Video-services company has a prepackaged plan involving a debt-for-equity swap with lenders. Deluxe Entertainment Services Group Inc., the video-services company backed by financier Ronald Perelman, filed for bankruptcy having reached a deal that will hand control of the company to its senior lenders.

title: Unconstitutional Tax Tricks
summary: The courts make quick work of liberal state legal stunts.. A federal judge on Tuesday blocked a California law compelling presidential candidates to disclose their income tax returns to appear on the state's primary ballot. This followed New York state's defeat Monday in its lawsuit claiming the 2017 tax reform is unconstitutional. Notice a trend here?

title: Harvard's Legal Discrimination
summary: A federal court upholds the university's race-conscious admissions.. Harvard University can racially discriminate in admissions against Asian-Americans to achieve a more diverse student body. That's the startling essence of a federal judge's ruling Tuesday that turns the 1964 Civil Rights Act on its head and seems destined for the Supreme Court.

title: Charter Schools Ace Another Test
summary: Minority students do better overall as charters gain market share.. Is the success of charter schools an illusion? Critics claim charters merely skim the best students, whose parents care enough to apply, while pushing out troublemakers. So it's worth noting a new study showing that often test scores improve for all students when charters increase their market share.

title: HP to Cut Up to 9,000 Jobs
summary: Printer-and-ink sales model gets makeover to revive lackluster earnings. Incoming HP Inc. Chief Executive Enrique Lores is moving quickly to imprint changes on the computer hardware maker with plans to shrink the company's ranks by as much as 16% in a restructuring plan that also aims to revive lagging printer sales.

title: Costco Reports Strong Sales
summary: Warehouse retailer speeding shipments of products before tariffs take effect. Costco Wholesale Corp. said Thursday that sales rose in the latest quarter, as the warehouse retailer works to offset the rising costs of tariffs.

title: The Streets of San Francisco
summary: The city made a choice to tolerate vagrancy and encourage drug use, with dire consequences.. San Francisco

title: Schiff's Shifty Timeline
summary: What did the House Intel Committee chairman know and when did he know it?. If the latest impeachment push continues to backfire, Democrats can thank their duplicitous House Intelligence chairman, Adam Schiff.

title: A Supercenter for Medicine
summary: Pols talk of reducing health costs. Walmart and CVS are doing something about it.. As politicians talk about how to reduce medical costs, Walmart and CVS are doing something about it. This month Walmart opened its first Health Center, in Dallas, Ga. It offers "primary care, labs, X-ray and EKG, counseling, dental, optical, hearing and community health education," all under one roof, a company press release announces.

title: #MeToo Should Include #SinToo
summary: America needs a secular Yom Kippur, a day of reflection and atonement.. Yom Kippur, the Jewish day of repentance, takes place Oct. 8-9 this year, right around the second anniversary of the #MeToo movement. If #MeToo began as a reckoning and is reshaping American politics, media and entertainment, perhaps Yom Kippur is an appropriate time for some reflection.

title: Sanders to Participate in Ohio Debate
summary: The 78-year-old Vermont senator had a procedure this week to insert stents to open an artery blockage. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders still plans to attend this month's Democratic presidential debate in Ohio, the campaign said, despite undergoing a procedure this week to open an artery blockage earlier this week.

title: 'Indistractable' Review: Fixing Our Attention
summary: A compendium of time-management strategies to help us stay better focused and ward off distractions.. I recently brought my 5-year-old son to Times Square for the first time. Unlike most native New Yorkers, he was entranced. Caught up in his excitement, I asked him, "Have you ever seen so many screens?" Gazing up as we walked across the street, he replied, "Yeah-I mean, no-and they're all distracting me."

title: Watergate, Vito Corleone and Trump's Impeachment
summary: The president's foes say he's abused the public trust. But there's little public trust to abuse.. Donald Trump studied at the Edgar Rice Burroughs School of Law, under Prof. Roy Cohn, among others. The law of the jungle is not the same law-elaborate, pettifogging, civilizing-that constrains the elites. Who is to say that the Burroughs School of Law is wrong in its approach to a world that is dangerous, uncertain and unjust? It turned young Lord Greystoke into Tarzan and Mr. Trump into the 45th president of the United States.

title: Pakistan Gives a Pass to China's Oppression of Muslims
summary: Prime Minister Imran Khan denounces Western 'Islamophobia' but shrugs at the Uighurs' plight.. Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan's foreign-policy agenda carries a contradiction at its heart. Mr. Khan seeks to project himself as a global defender of Islam, but he won't utter a peep about one of the most egregious persecutions of Muslims: China's repression of Xinjiang's Uighurs and its project to Sinicize Islam.

title: Notable & Quotable: Climate Change c. 2004
summary: 'Major European cities will be sunk beneath rising seas as Britain is plunged into a 'Siberian' climate by 2020.'. From "Now the Pentagon tells Bush: climate change will destroy us" in London's Observer, Feb. 21, 2004:

title: Digital Ad Companies to Merge
summary: The rival firms will join forces and operate under the Taboola name. Taboola Ltd. agreed to buy Outbrain Inc. in a cash-and-stock deal that will combine the internet's two largest content-recommendation companies.

title: New Uber App Pairs Gig Workers With Employers
summary: The launch comes as the company's core ride-hailing business is under immense financial and regulatory pressure. Uber Technologies Inc. has launched an app aimed at pairing businesses with temporary workers in an effort to bring in more revenue as the company struggles to turn a profit.

title: Prosecutors Charge Six Allegedly Linked to Death of HQ Trivia Co-Founder
summary: Indictment accuses alleged members of 'Mike's Candyshop' with ties to Colin Kroll's fatal overdose. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have charged six people with drug crimes who were allegedly linked to the overdose death of Colin Kroll, the co-founder of the HQ Trivia game app.

title: U.S. Officials Are Worried About Turkish Foray Into Syria
summary: A major incursion could prompt Trump administration to withdraw troops, essentially ending fight against Islamic State in Syria.

title: Euro Drifts Toward Its Lowest Level Against Dollar In Years
summary: Currency's outlook rests in part on who will be more aggressive in easing, the ECB or the Federal Reserve. The euro has drifted toward its lowest levels against the dollar in years as Europe takes the brunt of a global growth slowdown. Investors are now questioning: How low can it go?

title: Court Temporarily Halts New York's Ban on Sale of Flavored E-Cigarettes
summary: Ruling on a preliminary injunction expected at Oct. 18 court date.. A New York state regulation banning the sale of flavored e-cigarettes and vaping products has been put on hold by a state appellate court.

title: Hawaiian Airlines' Antitrust Request Turned Down
summary: U.S. regulator says the benefits from increased cooperation with Japan Airlines could be secured without antitrust immunity. U.S. regulators turned down a request by Hawaiian Airlines and Japan Airlines Co. for antitrust immunity to allow them to expand their cooperation, a rare blow that could further dent the patchwork of global alliances between carriers.

title: Health and Beauty Chains Work Ad Sales Into Their Regimens
summary: Drybar and Barry's Bootcamp moonlight as media channels for brands. Boutique beauty and health outlets Barry's Bootcamp LLC and Drybar Holdings LLC are bringing in a different sort of customer than their regulars: marketers eager to stand out in new ways.

title: MGM Resorts Reaches Settlement in 2017 Las Vegas Mass Shooting
summary: Casino company to pay up to $800 million to victims and families of those killed in largest-ever such settlement. In what legal experts say is the largest settlement of its kind stemming from a mass shooting, MGM Resorts International Inc. agreed Thursday to pay up to $800 million to victims of the 2017 massacre outside its Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.

title: Recession Scares Are Chipping Away at Investor Confidence
summary: Investors are thinking not about whether there will be a recession, but when it will be. Is this the big one? Poor manufacturing data this week have again amped up the volume on recession talk, and stocks fell sharply.

title: CFOs Could Look to Change Disclosure Practices Following Volkswagen Scandal
summary: Operational risk might need to be more of a focus, lawyers say. The legal aftermath of Volkswagen AG's emissions-cheating scandal could teach a lesson to finance chiefs about the right time to disclose critical information, particularly in the U.S., which differs from Europe in its disclosure requirements.

title: Metropolitan Opera Begins Sunday Shows
summary: Company ends longstanding tradition of not offering fully staged works on its traditional day of rest. To date, the Metropolitan Opera has presented Puccini's "Turandot" more than 300 times, going back to the work's first New York staging in 1926. But when the company offers a performance this weekend, it will be a markedly different occasion.

title: Buses Cruise Through Manhattan Corridor as Traffic Change Takes Effect
summary: Pilot program was so successful drivers needed to slow down to keep schedules. A new traffic change to speed up mass transit on one of Manhattan's busiest crosstown streets was so successful on its first day that bus drivers had to slow down to keep to their schedules.

title: Trump Removed Ukraine Envoy After Complaints From Giuliani, Others
summary: Marie Yovanovitch dismissed after Trump allies said she was blocking Biden probe and bad-mouthing president, people familiar with the matter say. WASHINGTON-President Trump ordered the removal of the ambassador to Ukraine after months of complaints from allies outside the administration, including his personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani, that she was undermining him abroad and obstructing efforts to persuade Kyiv to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Lobstermen Must Help to Save the Whales
summary: North Atlantic right whales may be at greater risk of serious injury and mortality in Maine waters than they are anywhere else in the U.S.. North Atlantic right whales may be at greater risk of serious injury and mortality in Maine waters than they are anywhere else in the U.S. ("Bid to Save Whales Grips Maine Lobstermen," U.S. News, Oct. 2). Entanglement in the vertical endlines used by commercial pot and trap fisheries, including the Maine lobster fishery, is heavily driving the right whale's dramatic decline and requires the administration's immediate and concerted attention.

title: Trump Targets Medicare for All in Re-Election Campaign
summary: President uses signing of executive order in Florida to lay out his actions on health policy. President Trump attacked Medicare for All on Thursday while laying out his own vision for health care, part of an effort to challenge Democratic presidential candidates proposing a federal system.

title: PepsiCo Revenue Climbs, but Profit Drops on Higher Expenses
summary: Increased ad spending helps fuel growth for the snack-and-beverage company. PepsiCo Inc.'s sales climbed in its latest quarter as increased spending on advertising drove growth while also damping earnings.

title: Massachusetts Vaping Ban Doesn't Include Out-of-State Purchases
summary: State officials say online, phone sales are fine-as long as delivery is beyond the state's borders. BOSTON-Health officials in Massachusetts are clarifying the state's four-month ban on the sale of all vaping products.

title: D.C. Arena Wants to Be the First Sports Venue to Add Gambling
summary: Betting firm William Hill and the owner of Washington's basketball and hockey teams plan to open a sportsbook inside Capital One Arena. Betting firm William Hill PLC and the owner of Washington's basketball and hockey teams plan to open a sportsbook inside the District of Columbia's Capital One Arena, in what would be the first wagering establishment inside a major-league venue in the U.S.

title: What to Know About Missing a Student-Loan Payment
summary: Default and delinquency are handled differently for federal and private loans. Many student-loan borrowers have difficulty making repayments, but they don't always realize the devastating, long-lasting financial consequences that can result from missed payments.

title: Stocks Bounce Back on Hopes for Rate Cut
summary: Worries over a possible economic downturn have grown this week, prompting rate-cut hopes. U.S. stocks rebounded Thursday after two sessions of dramatic losses as investors bet a string of disappointing economic data would spur the Federal Reserve to continue cutting interest rates.

title: Hatred and Anger Don't Foster a More Civil Society
summary: The young man who cursed Mr. Panero on the subway should look into the mirror and ask himself: Who filled my heart with so much hate, and what did they gain by turning me into a mindless agent of bigotry?. Thank you for publishing James Panero's harrowing account, "The Two Minutes Hate Comes to New York's Subway" (op-ed, Sept. 28). The young man who cursed Mr. Panero on the subway should look into the mirror and ask himself: Who filled my heart with so much hate, and what did they gain by turning me into a mindless agent of bigotry? Politicians, teachers, activists and media professionals who traffic in hatred and manipulate emotions to encourage such ugly actions should be recognized and held accountable.

title: Bill Would Pull the Plug on Vendors at Christmas Lights Extravaganza in Brooklyn
summary: Critics say event has been overrun with food and beverage stands, many without proper permits. For more than three decades, residents of Brooklyn's Dyker Heights have lavishly swathed their homes in lights and ornaments for the holiday season.

title: Shakespeare's Take on Trump Is a Subtle One
summary: Mr. Opelka may be correct about President Trump as King Lear, but Shakespeare's "Richard II" might also offer a relevant comparison.. Gregg Opelka uses Shakespeare's "King Lear" to suggest that President Trump's impeachment "will only rally those who actually understand him" ("Would Shakespeare Impeach Trump?," op-ed, Sept. 28). Mr. Opelka may be correct, but Shakespeare's "Richard II" might also offer a relevant comparison. In "Richard II," the King mismanages England's funds, drains its coffers, lies, manipulates and disposes of his political rivals. The people rise up and the play concludes with Richard II dying in prison. In this comparison, it appears that Shakespeare would support the impeachment of President Trump. Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" may also be pertinent for it portrays the tragic chaos that can occur upon the forcible removal (i.e. "impeachment" at the end of a blade) of a country's leader. As usual, Shakespeare's wisdom can prove enigmatic.

title: Federal Flood Policies Affect Whole Regions
summary: Walter Block's libertarian flood insurance proposal will spell fiscal disaster worse than a hurricane disaster for many coastal counties.. Walter E. Block notes that Canada has a harsh policy of forced buyouts that requires homeowners in flooded areas to relocate ("U.S. Largess vs. Canadian Cruelty," op-ed, Sept. 19). By contrast, in an area such as the Outer Banks of North Carolina that has been hit by three hurricanes in the last four years, the government offered subsidies to residents who stayed and rebuilt. Mr. Block favors a personal responsibility approach: Homeowners should be free to rebuild after a flood, but then they should be on their own regarding private insurance to protect their properties.

title: Paying Our Teachers Better Requires Pension Reform
summary: If we want to claim that we're all in this together, it's time to stop pretending that economics only applies to the private sector.. Daniel DiSalvo grazes the edge of the solution to the teacher pay-pension crisis, but then quickly eschews it ("Teachers Want Higher Pay, but Pensions Swallow Up the Money," op-ed, Oct. 1). He notes that "outside of bankruptcy it is legally impossible to reduce [teachers'] pensions." Well, there you have it. Bankruptcy proceedings to reform these unsustainable pensions won't be popular, nor will they be ideal for those teachers who have planned and counted on them, and people will ask how dare we visit this injustice upon those charged with teaching our children? Unfortunately, this same injustice was visited upon the parents of many of these children, especially in states such as Illinois, West Virginia and Kentucky as manufacturing fled those states.

title: Big Brewer to Launch Corona-Spiked Seltzer as Pot Bet Sours
summary: Constellation Brands posted a quarterly loss following its investment last year in Canadian marijuana grower Canopy Growth. Constellation Brands Inc.'s big bet on cannabis has been a drag on profits, but the brewer is preparing its next gamble: jumping into the crowded, fast-growing market for alcoholic seltzers with a new Corona-branded drink.

title: GoPro's Ghost of Heroes Past
summary: Action camera maker's latest production problems call up painful memories. GoPro investors should know by now to not get too excited.

title: Services Stumble Threatens Sharper Slowdown
summary: Services-sector data suggest a manufacturing downturn is spreading. U.S. services-sector activity last month expanded at its slowest pace in three years, prompting concerns a manufacturing downturn is spreading across the economy.

title: U.S. Bonds Extend Rally After Service-Sector Data
summary: Yield on the 10-year Treasury settles below 1.53%.. U.S. government bonds extended recent gains Thursday after disappointing service-sector data added to concerns about the U.S. economy.

title: No Collusion Between Financial Times Reporters, Wirecard Short Sellers, Review Finds
summary: German payments company has consistently denied FT's reporting about its accounting practices and potential financial misconduct. An outside review of The Financial Times's coverage of German payments company Wirecard AG found no collusion between reporters and short sellers looking to benefit by drops in the company's stock price, the newspaper said Thursday.

title: 'Press' Review: Papers Tear Into One Another
summary: This 'Masterpiece' series looks at the conflict between two British newspapers: a sensationalist tabloid and a left-leaning broadsheet.. In this ebullient saga set in contemporary London, about two British newspapers engaged in mortal combat, competing reporters cheat and lie to get scoops, they run themselves ragged, they don't seem to have personal lives, and nobody is scouring Facebook. All of which lends "Press" (begins Sunday, 10 p.m., PBS) a distinct touch of old-school flavor that only deepens as the battles over journalistic ethics grow more intense. As does the oratory.

title: Industrial Design Gets Family-Friendly in a Chicago Loft
summary: A designer honors-but softens-the warehouse aesthetic of a young family's hundred-year-old loft. ALL THE FLUSH Wall Street arrivistes who bought lofts in the 1990s wouldn't want you to know this dirty secret: Exposed-brick walls and cavernous spaces can feel as cold as a spelunking trip. That lack of a snuggle factor was something Sara and Jan Zasowski soon acknowledged after buying a loft in Chicago's River North neighborhood for themselves and their now-2-year-old son-a real problem in a city that clocked three continuous days below zero in 2018. The pair, a psychotherapist and trader, often invite friends for game nights. "We like minimalist design, but it needs to be comfortable because we're always hosting people," said Ms. Zasowski.

title: Facebook Must Remove More Content if Ordered, EU Rules
summary: Court rules tech giant must comply with judges' orders to remove reposts. The European Union's top court gave judges in the bloc broader power to order the removal of Facebook posts, dealing a fresh blow to the U.S. tech giant as it faces growing regulatory headwinds on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: 'Joker': The Laugh's on Us
summary: Joaquin Phoenix gives a piercingly intense performance in an otherwise grim film..

title: 'Dolemite Is My Name': A Twofer Tribute
summary: Eddie Murphy stars as a legend of black entertainment in this ode to outrageous humor.. In "Dolemite Is My Name," Eddie Murphy takes a good idea and runs with it, soars with it, and turns it into a great, if wildly erratic, twofer tribute-to a singular legend of black entertainment culture, and to the transformative power of raunchy, outrageous humor. Mr. Murphy, whose big-screen career has been hovering somewhere between abeyance and abdication in recent years, also scores a twofer triumph of performance with phenomenal comic energy. He plays the 1970s comedian Rudy Ray Moore, as well as Moore's extravagant alter ego, the profane pimp and eponymous hero of his debut film, "Dolemite," which was surely the worst blaxploitation picture ever made, and arguably the most beloved.

title: 'Pain and Glory' Review: Portrait of the Artist as an Aging Man
summary: In director Pedro Almodóvar's semiautobiographical story, Antonio Banderas plays a filmmaker suffering physically and spiritually.. Pedro Almodóvar has given us immeasurable pleasure over the decades. Now, in "Pain and Glory," he gives us a version of his aging self in pain, and confronted by the anguishing prospect of life without work. Put "version" in DayGlo pastels, though. The words "Almodóvar" and "anguish" are mutually exclusive, at least on the screen, so this semiautobiographical tale, with Antonio Banderas as the filmmaker's surrogate, Salvador Mallo, mixes darkness with light, melancholia with drollery, nostalgia with renewal, and regret for lost love with ineffable tenderness.

title: EU Pledges Restraint as U.S. Moves to Add Tariffs
summary: Officials signal they want to avoid a broader trade war after Trump administration takes advantage of WTO ruling on Airbus to impose additional levies. BRUSSELS-The European Union signaled it wouldn't immediately retaliate against new U.S. tariffs, seeking to avoid a broader trade war as Washington moves to punish the bloc over Airbus SE subsidies the World Trade Organization ruled illegal.

title: 'Freestyle Love Supreme' Review: More Nightclub Act Than Broadway Show
summary: A program of work by a hip-hop improv comedy troupe with Lin-Manuel Miranda's name attached is sure to be popular, but doesn't fit its setting.. New York

title: Fed's Mester Warns Low Rates Can Fuel Financial Imbalances
summary: She echoes concern that low borrowing costs can contribute to asset bubbles, overreliance by companies and households on cheap debt. WASHINGTON-Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said Thursday there was a risk of financial imbalances developing in an environment of low interest rates and that the central bank had relatively few tools to address such issues outside of monetary policy.

title: Big Tobacco's Longest-Serving CEO Unexpectedly Resigns
summary: Alison Cooper's planned departure comes amid mounting regulatory headwinds buffeting the industry. LONDON-The chief executive of Imperial Brands PLC, Big Tobacco's longest-serving CEO, has unexpectedly resigned, the latest fallout from regulatory headwinds buffeting the industry.

title: Soybean Futures Bounce Back After China Restarts Purchases
summary: Traders capitalize on cooler trade tensions ahead of next week's talks. Soybean prices have rallied since China resumed purchases of the key U.S. crop ahead of trade talks in Washington next week.

title: How Home Equity Affects College Aid
summary: The rules vary dramatically between schools on how much of your home equity will be used to calculate an aid package. Fall is hunting season across the U.S., a time when high-school seniors target their favorite colleges and their parents aim for financial aid.

title: 'Flash Drought' Hits South as Record Heat Continues
summary: Thermometers climbed above 100 Tuesday; Tallahassee had only trace amounts of rainfall in September. Across the South, residents and farmers are facing a double punch of hot temperatures and drought even as the calendar has flipped to fall.

title: FTC Probes E-Cigarette Sales and Promotional Methods
summary: Study comes as health authorities urge people to stop using vaping products while they investigate a rash of illnesses and deaths linked to vaping. The Federal Trade Commission said it is seeking information from six e-cigarette companies, including vaping startup Juul Labs Inc., to study the sale and promotion of their products as health authorities investigate a rash of illnesses and deaths linked to vaping.

title: 'Ogresse' Review: A Beauty About a Beast
summary: Cécile McLorin Salvant's song cycle about a flesh-eating monster is a stunningly original epic that draws on myriad musical genres.. New York

title: Bayer Executive Joins Johnson & Johnson as CIO
summary: Jim Swanson has roots in Bayer's crop-science division, where he led data-science initiatives. Jim Swanson, formerly a technology executive at Bayer AG's crop-science division, has joined Johnson & Johnson as chief information officer.

title: Amazon Clashes With Disney Over Terms for Offering Apps in Fire TV
summary: Disney resists Amazon push for some of the ad revenue from entertainment giant's apps. Amazon.com Inc. and Walt Disney Co. are at loggerheads over terms for carrying the entertainment giant's apps in Amazon's Fire TV devices, a dispute that highlights the new power struggles emerging in the streaming economy.

title: Weinstein Trial Must Remain in Manhattan, Appeals Court Rules
summary: The film producer is set to go to trial in January on criminal charges including rape. A New York state appeals court ruled Thursday that the criminal trial of Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein must remain in Manhattan.

title: This Is the Affordable Work Shoe Men Need
summary: Unlike its chunky, punky boots, Dr. Martens's round-toe dress shoes blend in around the office. And at only $120, they're a relative steal. NEEDED: A PAIR of simple oxford shoes that are work-appropriate, but not so work-appropriate they'd look stodgy at the bar. An unexpected place to seek inspiration? Your high-school yearbook, where, in a black-and-white shot of the cool kids using the darkroom, you might spy a pair of classic, black "1461" Dr. Martens oxfords. Today, those shoes have been updated in a subtle, matte, black-on-black variation without the telltale yellow stitching. Less teen, more clean.

title: Hong Kong to Invoke Emergency Powers to Tackle Protests
summary: Move to ban masks would be the first time emergency law is used in more than half a century. HONG KONG-Authorities here are planning to invoke a British colonial-era law for the first time in half a century to ban people from wearing masks at protests, people familiar with the matter said, as police struggle to contain spiralling violent unrest throughout Hong Kong.

title: 'The Secret Commonwealth' Review: Philip Pullman's 'Book of Dust' Continued
summary: In the second volume of an unfolding trilogy, we're reminded that heroine Lyra is more than a girl; she is one prophesied, a fulcrum of destiny yet to tip the cosmic scales.. In Philip Pullman's most celebrated fantasy realm, there's no closer relationship than that between a person and his or her daemon-a kind of external soul in the shape of an animal-and no greater horror than the separation of the two. For the self to be sundered causes physical and emotional agony. Those who survive are wounded, freakish, their separation a cause of shuddering revulsion in others. So it's painful to return to the richly imagined world of Lyra Belacqua, aka Lyra Silvertongue, to find that she and her daemon, the soft-furred pine marten Pantalaimon, are alienated to the point of hostility.

title: Lawyer Gets One-Month Prison Term in College-Admissions Case
summary: 'Shame and humiliation haunt me,' Gordon Caplan said. BOSTON-The former co-chairman of law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP was sentenced Thursday to one month in prison for his role in the college admissions cheating scheme, as the federal judge overseeing the cases of parents who have pleaded guilty continued to distinguish between parents who were involved in the testing scheme and those who bribed coaches to secure spots at particular colleges.

title: U.S. Expects to Hold On to Measles Elimination Status
summary: Its designation as having eliminated the infectious disease, dating to 1999, was at risk as a result of outbreaks in New York State. Federal health authorities expect the U.S. will retain its coveted status as a nation that has eliminated domestic transmission of measles, dodging a bullet after outbreaks in New York state threatened the designation.

title: When a Home Is Suddenly Called 'Historic'
summary: Historic designations are becoming controversial as third parties seek landmark status on a home, often against the homeowner's wishes, as a way to block demolition or development of a property. Merrill and Karen King had just signed a contract last October to sell their four-bedroom, four-bathroom, 3,096-square-foot home, and three adjacent buildable lots, in St. Petersburg, Fla., to a developer for $960,000. Their circa-1925 home was known locally as the Doc Webb property, named after a previous owner, James Earl "Doc" Webb, who in 1928 founded Webb's City, a drugstore that is considered the precursor to the department store and that helped put St. Petersburg on the map.

title: Retailers Give Sunny Holiday Forecast but Sound a Warning
summary: National Retail Federation expects sales to rise as much as 4.2%, but says global uncertainty could blunt spending. Retailers expect a strong holiday shopping season, but warn that global political and economic uncertainty could erode consumer confidence and spending.

title: Thousands of Schools Fall Below Recommended Measles Vaccination Rate
summary: Even as outbreaks end, pockets of low vaccination leave local communities vulnerable to outbreaks, WSJ examination finds. Thousands of individual schools in the U.S. don't have high enough immunization levels to meet the threshold considered adequate to protect a population from measles, a Wall Street Journal examination found.

title: L.A. Spec Home Market Notches Win with Roughly $43M Sale
summary: The elaborate Beverly Hills Post Office home was partially financed by a pair of British billionaires. An elaborate Los Angeles spec mansion has sold for roughly $43 million to a buyer in the private equity sector, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Iraq Struggles to Contain Antigovernment Protests
summary: Authorities impose a curfew in Baghdad, restrict the internet after at least 17 people were killed, up to 800 wounded in demonstrations. BAGHDAD-Iraq imposed a curfew in Baghdad and restricted access to the internet in a bid to quell the biggest antigovernment protests since Prime Minister Adel Abdul-Mahditook office a year ago.

title: Treasury to Sell $193 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department's auctions next week will range from 13-week bills to 30-year bonds. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $193 billion in securities next week, comprising $108 billion in new debt and $85 billion in previously sold debt. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: The False Divide Between Locals and Citizens of the World
summary: Loyalty isn't a zero-sum sentiment, and most of us manage to combine devotion to community with global concerns.. The political split between left and right, we've been told, is being overtaken by an emerging realignment. "The struggle between the open and closed visions of society may well be the most important political contest in the world right now," according to The Economist. Fareed Zakaria has argued that we've entered "a new ideological era, one defined by an 'open-closed' divide-between people comfortable in a world of greater openness in trade, technology and migration and those who want more barriers, protections and restraints. Parties of the future will likely be positioned along this new spectrum."

title: After Nike Coach's Suspension, His Star Pupil Faces Scrutiny
summary: Galen Rupp has been the longtime center of attention for the Nike Oregon Project and coach Alberto Salazar, now serving a four-year sanction for doping conduct. DOHA, Qatar-When Alberto Salazar thought he was dying, his mind turned to Galen Rupp.

title: Small Business Hiring Slows
summary: Latest NFIB survey finds continuing labor shortage and higher pay for workers.. Small businesses are hiring but still struggling to find help-even as they raise wages. According to the latest monthly employment report from the National Federation of Independent Business, due out later today:

title: Lazard Plans Cuts in Asset Management
summary: Cutting of investment staff and others follows firm's annual review. Lazard Ltd. is cutting up to 7% of its employees in its asset-management division and closing some investment funds by year's end, people familiar with the matter said, amid a tougher climate for money managers.

title: 'Active Interest': Insurance Tycoon Spied on Women Who Caught His Eye
summary: Resume Subscription. Federal investigators were closing in on Greg Lindberg. FBI agents confronted the North Carolina insurance tycoon last year as they probed whether he tried to bribe a state regulator. In March, officials obtained a sealed warrant for his arrest. His attorneys were negotiating his surrender.

title: Cars' Pedestrian-Safety Features Often Fail, Study Finds
summary: AAA finds pedestrian detection ineffective at night, when most deaths occur. New safety features being rolled out by auto makers to keep drivers from hitting pedestrians don't work at times in some of the most dangerous situations and frequently fail at night, according to a new study by AAA.

title: Pepsi Rises to the Challenge
summary: Under its new chief executive, Pepsi is making the right investments to succeed in a difficult consumer environment. The fizz is back at PepsiCo as the company's investment campaign begins to pay off.

title: Salt and Pepper Are No Longer Enough
summary: More varied flavors in our cuisine call for bolder additions at the table, from chili flakes and wasabi to fish sauce and chaat masala. On my mother-in-law's table there are always at least two sets of salt and pepper, in old-fashioned mills, arranged at thoughtful intervals so that everyone can reach them. What a new guest to her table may not realize is that these little grinders come with an unspoken rule. Only take the pepper, never the salt. I discovered this one evening when I salted my soup and my mother-in-law reacted as if I had punched her on the nose. She is a superb cook, trained in the French tradition, and by adding salt at the table, I had implied, rudely, that her seasoning could be improved. She doesn't feel the same about pepper, which you are at liberty to grind until you make yourself sneeze. My mother-in-law views pepper as a condiment, meaning that it is at the discretion of the eater and not the cook.

title: Finally, Feel Free to Return That Library Book You Checked Out in 1981
summary: Libraries battling to retain borrowers in the digital age are ending late fees, a change intended to ease the shame and dread of returning overdue books. Casey Kidik was in fifth grade when she came across a copy of "Julie of the Wolves." She had checked it out as a second-grader from the public library in Carver, Mass. By the time she rediscovered the book, the family had moved to Plymouth.

title: Old Swiss Franc Mortgages Could Come Back to Haunt Polish Banks
summary: European Court of Justice rules in favor of consumers who took out mortgages tied to the franc and got hit when the currency and their repayments soared. The European Union's top court ruled in favor Thursday of Polish consumers who took out low-rate mortgages tied to the Swiss franc years ago, only to see the currency and their repayments soar-potentially leaving banks on the hook for billions of dollars.

title: The Chaos of Weather Forecasts
summary: In principle, math should be able to tell us whether it will rain tomorrow-but in practice, things get complicated quickly.. In the days before I have to travel, I start checking the weather forecast to see what I'll need to pack and if my flight is likely to be delayed. At this time of year, as the seasons are shifting, the forecast seems particularly prone to changing every day, sometimes even hour by hour. If the weather forecast is wrong, we might be tempted to blame the meteorologists, but it could be the fault of the mathematics.

title: Four Officers Killed by Employee at Paris Police Headquarters
summary: Police say attacker worked in the IT department and suspect the attack stemmed from an office dispute. PARIS-An administrative worker with the French police stabbed and killed four officers at the police headquarters on Thursday before he was gunned down.

title: A Lucky Escape for Europe's Luxury Brands
summary: Champagne and designer handbag companies dodged U.S. tariffs this time around, but the risks of tying production to specific terroirs are clear. Manufacturers of luxury handbags and champagne got lucky in the latest round of U.S. tariffs, but they still need to prepare for a less globalized world.

title: You're in Your 60s and Haven't Saved Enough. Here's What to Do.
summary: Retirement columnist Glenn Ruffenach also sheds light on converting 401(k)s to Roth IRAs. My wife and I are in our early 60s and, for various reasons, haven't saved enough for retirement. What are your best suggestions for pumping up our nest egg? We already plan to continue working into our mid-60s and, if necessary, beyond.

title: Home Runs Will Decide Baseball's Postseason
summary: The long ball defined the regular season, and they will almost certainly decide who survives in October. Every year around this time, the New York Yankees' manager faces some variation of the same question, and it drives him crazy. Joe Torre heard it. Joe Girardi heard it. And now Aaron Boone is hearing it: Do the Yankees lean too much on home runs to succeed in the playoffs?

title: Meeting-Space Companies See Big Money in Manhattan
summary: U.K. firm etc.venues' expansion in New York challenges hotels and others for a slice of the $10 billion conference and event business. A British company that builds and rents out meeting space in office properties is expanding in New York City, challenging hotels and other operators for a slice of the city's more than $10 billion annual conference business.

title: New York Fed Adds About $33.6 Billion to Financial System
summary: Repo market is used to relieve funding pressure in money markets. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $33.55 billion to the financial system Thursday by using the market for repurchase agreements, or repo, to relieve funding pressure in money markets.

title: Want to Buy This Sweater? First, You Have to Adopt the Sheep
summary: Sweater brand Sheep Inc. bills sheep "adoption" as a way to offset the carbon footprint of each of its sweaters ten times over. They want other companies to replicate their model. The company Sheep Inc. sells just one product. Debuting today, its unisex sweater is made from cashwool, a merino blend that's soft like cashmere and temperature-regulating like wool. Its design is classic, its fit not baggy or too tight. The five colors it comes in-three neutrals, plus clay red and Pacific blue-go with almost anything.

title: The 5 Best-Designed Items of October
summary: A gym shoe for gadget lovers, a chic guide to New York City and the new must-have timepiece: WSJ. Magazine editors round up five new design items they're most excited about.. The Swedish museum Fotografiska has been championing photography since it opened in Stockholm in 2010. With an outpost in Tallinn, Estonia, and plans underway for a London space, Fotografiska is debuting a New York satellite this winter in an ornate Park Avenue South building. Ellen von Unwerth, Adi Nes and Lars Tunbjörk, whose 1991 photo Öland is above, are among the artists featured in the inaugural shows. In addition, the six-story museum's second floor is devoted to a Roman and Williams-designed restaurant, overseen by restaurateur Stephen Starr. fotografiska.com

title: Mandatory Gun Buybacks Divide 2020 Democrats, Activists
summary: Gun-rights supporters oppose a government mandate to buy assault-style weapons; some gun-control advocates are also wary of the idea. LAS VEGAS-Democratic presidential candidates and gun-control advocates are divided on whether the government should mandate buybacks of assault-style weapons, with some fearing it could jeopardize goals such as broadening background checks.

title: What Makes You Nostalgic?
summary: Author Michael Lewis on how misty-eyed feelings toward the past can be exploited for financial gain. Plus five other luminaries on this month's topic: nostalgia. "There's money to be made off exploiting other people's nostalgia. Baseball, unlike other sports, is selling its connection to the past. I think that's why baseball is nostalgic. People naturally associate baseball not just with childhood but with their relationship with their father. If what you're selling is continuity and a connection to the childhood experience, then it is scary to make changes. If you make those changes, you do indeed undermine that feeling of nostalgia. It's not irrational for these sorts of institutions to be resistant to change. The interesting thing is that baseball is so unmodern. The modern world is all about embracing change and disrupting. The truth about baseball is if there's no continuity, it's kind of boring. It's slow; it's not the pace of modern life. Basketball is the pace of modern life."

title: U.K. Farmers Rush to Sell Produce Ahead of October Brexit Deadline
summary: 'Fire sale' is under way as British farmers and European importers lock in sales before a potential no-deal Brexit. British farmers are racing to ship this year's abundant harvest out of the U.K. by Halloween, when Brexit could pull the country out of the world's biggest free-trade zone overnight.

title: Rates of Twin Births in U.S. Drop After Rising for Decades
summary: Decline occurred among white mothers aged 30-54, CDC data says. The rate of twins born in the U.S. dropped 4% from 2014 to 2018 after roughly three decades of increases, according to a new report from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Stocks Are Off to Ominous Start in Fourth Quarter
summary: While indexes usually notch their biggest gains at this time, a strong showing in 2019 will be hard. The next three months should be the most wonderful time of the year for the stock market. summary: Postcrisis regulations may have played role in recent funding-market disruptions, but that doesn't mean they are about to change. summary: Activity has been on a downward trajectory since early 2018. Global manufacturing activity contracted in September, the fifth time in as many months, and has been slowing since early 2018, with nearly every major economy taking a hit, IHS Markit data show.

title: End of Tax Season Is Near, and Accountants Are (Almost) Ready
summary: Oct. 15 extended deadline for filing returns is especially challenging this year under new tax law. You thought tax season concluded six months ago? Nope. summary: Buybacks are booming and engaged investors are getting clear results. Japan's corporate governance reforms are starting to pay off, and plenty more could be coming. This is a good reason to get excited about the country's cheap stocks, even if growth prospects aren't exciting.

title: U.S. Prosecutor Alleges 'El Chapo' Channeled $1 Million Bribe to Honduran President
summary: The accusation was made at the opening of the drug-trafficking trial of the president's brother. title: Barneys Finds a Potential Buyer in Bankruptcy Court
summary: Group led by trade-show executive Sam Ben-Avraham is preparing a $220 million bid for retailer. A group of fashion executives is preparing a roughly $220 million bid to take control of Barneys New York Inc., according to people familiar with the situation, as the bankrupt retailer seeks to avoid a liquidation.

title: BlackRock in Talks With Tencent on China Tie-Up
summary: The New York money manager is seeking a bigger presence in China. title: Former Dallas Officer Sentenced to 10 Years for Shooting of Black Neighbor
summary: White policewoman shot her black neighbor in his apartment, believing it was her own; 'I love you as a person,' the victim's brother said, forgiving the shooter. DALLAS-A former Dallas police officer was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Wednesday after a jury convicted her of murder for shooting and killing her upstairs neighbor when she walked into the wrong apartment.

title: U.S. to Impose Tariffs on EU Goods After Airbus Ruling
summary: Global trade regulator gave Washington green light in ruling on EU subsidies for Airbus. title: GoPro Cuts Outlook for Second Half of Year
summary: Maker of action cameras cited production delays on latest offering. GoPro Inc. lowered financial targets for the latter half of the year, due primarily to production delays for the latest Hero8 Black cameras.
